Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships for Future Leaders in Electric Energy and Smart Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF S-STEM program provides scholarships for recruitment and retention of students in the area of electric energy and smart grid applications. The program builds on a nationally leading power engineering education and research program at Washington State University (WSU). This program offers approximately 19 scholarships per year. The objectives are to increase the number of students in power engineering at WSU by 50% for the following groups: Bachelor's, Master's, underrepresented minorities, and women. This program provides opportunities for lower division WSU students, community college students, and four-year university students to study at WSU for Bachelor's and Master's degrees. It builds on existing support structures at WSU to offer opportunities in a bridging program, faculty and industry mentorships, tutors, study groups, internships, field trips, and a hallmark annual poster event. The program is strongly supported by major power companies in Washington that provide industry mentorships and internships opportunities. Undergraduate and graduate students participate in projects supervised by WSU Energy Systems Innovation Center faculty. This project is particularly important for Washington and the Pacific Northwest, where the energy sector has a significant share of the global market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the Scholarships for Future Leaders in Electric Energy and Smart Grid project was to increase enrollment in electric energy-related STEM majors at Washington State University at both the bachelor's and master's levels, subsequently increasing the number of well-educated employees in the field of smart grid employment, a critical growth area in the United States. To achieve this goal, this program offered financial support in the form of scholarships to eligible students based on their need and merit and further offered several support programs including (i) power practicum at our member utility sites every year in March during the spring break, (ii) encouraging attendance in local conferences and covering the cost from local resources e.g., for Western Protective Relay Conference in Spokane (every October), (iii) the senior poster competition, held in late April. As a result of these efforts, awareness of power engineering as a career field has grown, especially internally within the WSU Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture. We made a total of 81 scholarships (to 45 students, accounting for renewals), of which 20% were females and 22% were among the underrepresented minority groups. We recruited 5 students into our M.Sc. program, and two of our scholars have been ranked top among WSU EECS undergraduate students. These students represent a 200% increase in the number of U.S. master's students in power engineering.
